items.title: Royal Mineral Water Hospital, Bath
items.summary: Architect: John Wood the Elder Date: 1738-42 Description: The Royal Mineral Water Hospital was founded in 1738. It provided care…
items.content_html:
Architect: John Wood the Elder

Date: 1738-42

Description:

The Royal Mineral Water Hospital was founded in 1738. It provided care for the impoverished sick who were attracted to Bath because of the supposed healing properties of the mineral water. The original building was designed by John Wood the Elder and built with Bath stone donated by Ralph Allen and was completed in 1742.

The attic storey was added later in 1793.

items.summary: Architect: John Wood the Younger Date: 1773 Description: Acton Castle over looking St Michael’s Mount in Cornwall was built in…
items.content_html:
Architect: John Wood the Younger

Date: 1773

Description:

Acton Castle over looking St Michael’s Mount in Cornwall was built in 1773. It was designed by John Wood the Younger and constructed in brick faced with local Cornish granite, for John Stackhouse who was a marine biologist. 

It now split into apartments with five of them being available as holiday lets. For more information actoncastle.com.

items.title: All Saints Church, Woolley
items.summary: Architect: John Wood the Younger Date: 1761 Description: All Saints Church, Woolley is situated just four miles north west of…
items.content_html:
Architect: John Wood the Younger

Date: 1761

Description:

All Saints Church, Woolley is situated just four miles north west of Bath.

The Church was built on the site of an earlier chapel in 1761 by John Wood the Younger. It was paid for by Mrs Elizabeth Parkin who was the owner of the nearby gunpowder factory in Woolley. 

For more information about the Gunpowder Factory

It is also the final resting place of Admiral Puget who surveyed Puget Sound in the Pacific North West America near Seattle that bears his name.

In the distance the Church of St Mary in Upper Swainswick which is the resting place of his father John Wood the Elder.

Thorpe’s Map of Bath 1743 (below), showing the previous church at Woolley, the Gunpowder Factory at Woolley and also St Mary’s Church in Upper Swainswick.

items.title: Belcomb Brook, Bradford Upon Avon
items.summary: Architect: John Wood the Elder Date: 1734 Description: In 1734 Francis Yerbury commissioned John Wood the Elder to design him…
items.content_html:
Architect: John Wood the Elder

Date: 1734

Description:

In 1734 Francis Yerbury commissioned John Wood the Elder to design him a new house. Belcomb Brook (Known today as Belcombe Court) has been extended since, but you can still see the facade that John Wood the Elder designed. A print of his design is in his book *‘A Descripton of Bath’* where he also descibes the Villa:

"This Villa is a small Addition to some other Buildings erected for the Offices and Work Houses proper for one concerned in the Cloathing Manufacture…"

"…it consists of a Cellar Story almost sunk into the Ground, and this sustains a Principal and half Story… Front is adorned with Pilasters of the lonick Order, forming the best Tetrastyle Frontispiece, in square Pillars of that Order, that hath been yet executed in or about Bath : The Windows of the principal Story are dressed so as to be come compleate Tabernacles, while those of the half Story are adorned with single Architraves ; and the Mouldings in the whole Front, proper to be carved, are all enriched in the best Manner the Workmen were then Masters of."

"The Principal Story is divided into an Anti-room ; a Parlour, of twenty Feet Square ; and an Octangular Study, of twelve Feet Diameter, over which there are two Alcove Bed Chambers, with a Dressing Room between them : And the Altitude of the lower Rooms being twelve Feet, it admitted of a Cove round the Study ; the Flat Ceiling of which is adorned with a Bas-Relief, in Stucco, performed by a Workman of great Skill in his Profession."

"The two Ends of Belcomb-Brook-Villa the one fronting to the Eastward, the other to the Westward, are finished with Pediments, or Footments to the Roof of the Building…"
